awd_titl_txt: EAGER: GaP-diamond photonic-spin devices for scalable quantum information processing
awd_abstract_narration:
Overview:
The objective of this EAGER proposal is to determine the feasibility of a scalable quantum optical network based on NV-centers in diamond coupled to gallium phosphide (GaP) photonic devices. Two critical components necessary for scalability will be fabricated and implemented:  (1) large-area GaP-diamond integration and device fabrication and (2) independent electrical tuning of quantum device frequencies on the same chip. If successful, this research will pave the way toward a large-scale quantum information processor (QIP) that could be utilized for secure communication, quantum algorithms, and quantum simulation.

Intellectual Merit:
This research proposal identifies the GaP-diamond hybrid material system as an extremely promising system to realize a scalable measurement-based quantum information network. In the hybrid system, the GaP provides the photonic device layer while the diamond nitrogen-vacancy (NV) center provides the photon-coupled spin qubit. The proposed work addresses the major challenges in diamond-GaP integration. The first specific goal of this project is the deterministic transfer and bonding of a GaP membrane to a diamond chip with an area capable of supporting one hundred integrated devices. In addition to QIP applications, the technique developed is expected to have applications in classical photonics due to GaP's wide bandgap and electro-optic properties.  The second goal is the electric tuning of near-surface NV centers onto resonance with on-chip GaP cavities in three or more devices on the same chip. If realized, this will be the first demonstration of device specific electrical tuning of a quantum emitter onto an optical cavity resonance and will be an important milestone for all photonic-spin solid-state qubit systems.

Broader Impacts:
The development of NV centers integrated into on-chip optical devices is expected to lead to scalable quantum information processing (QIP). Scalable QIP will enable long-distance secure communication, factoring of products of large-prime numbers in polynomial time, and the efficient simulation of many-body quantum systems critical for engineering new materials. Historically, scalability has proven to be a challenge in quantum information processing because typically quantum bits with good quantum properties have not been realized in a solid-state system, prohibiting device fabrication and integration. Broader impacts of the proposed research process include developing public software to implement finite-difference-time-domain (FDTD) electromagnetic simulations on a virtual computer cluster on the Amazon cloud and training both graduate and undergraduate students.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
This research was conducted to determine if a hybrid photonics platform, composed of diamond, for quantum resources, and gallium phosphide for photonics, could be fabricated in a scalable manner.  The long-term application of this research is to develop a scalable hardware platform for quantum information processing. It has been realized for some time now that quantum resources, if realized in a robust and scalable manner, can be utilized to solve computation problems that currently cannot be solved on today’s computers. 

 

The project resulted in two main outcomes. First, we demonstrated the fabrication of small photonic circuits, comprised of several essential optical components, in our proposed platform. Previously, only single optical components had been realized.  Next, we designed and built an automated photonic test system that enabled us to benchmark the performance of hundreds of devices fabricated on a single diamond chip. This mass characterization is rarely performed for quantum optical devices, despite the pressing need as these technologies become more developed.  Based on these measurements, we found we can expect a device yield of 10% for an important quantum circuit that would generate entanglement, a computational resource. This result is promising for a scalable platform in which it is possible to fabricate thousands of devices from which hundreds of working devices can be connected.

 

During the course of the award, 2 PhD students and 2 undergraduate students were trained to conduct research in this emerging area of quantum nanophotonics.  One PhD student graduated and was employed in the semiconductor industry in the Pacific Northwest. One undergraduate graduated and is currently in a PhD program in physics.

 


Last Modified: 11/28/2015
Modified by: Kai-Mei Fu
